bibl.title: Letter from Thurman B. Rice to Philip Showalter Hench, April 13, 1948

div1.p: In connection with Hench's efforts to learn more about Reed's 1900 Indianapolis lecture, Rice sends Hench a list of hotels in the city at that date. He also encloses a letter from Rice to Fletcher Hodges, a friend and long-time Indianapolis resident, which includes Hodges' reply to Rice. Hodges has crossed out some of the hotels on the list.

div1.head: Letter from Thurman B. Rice to Philip Showalter Hench, April 13, 1948
div1.opener:
INDIANA UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER
1040-1232 WEST MICHIGAN STREET
INDIANAPOLIS 7, INDIANA
April 13, 1948
File Y F
Write
Hotel English
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Enclosed you will find a list of hotels to be found in Indianapolis
as of 1900. The list was prepared by the reference department of
the Indianapolis Public Library. Also you will find a letter which
I wrote to a physician friend of mine who lived in Indianapolis from
the time of his birth and was a young man in 1900. He came from a
very old and prominent family and was in position to know more about
the subject matter under discussion than anyone I know. You will
note the note which he has written at the bottom of my own letter.

He tells me and I think that he is quite correct in all probability,
that the hotels which he has marked out are clearly out of the ques-
tion. Those that he checked are rather prominent hotels. There is
one instance where he has put one check mark over two names, the
Hotel English and the Hotel Oneida. I think probably that he meant
for the check to be after the Hotel English. I am inclined to think
that he meant to draw a line through the Hotel Oneida and just neg-
lected to do so. I believe I am correct when I say that the Oneida
was somewhat questionable. Maybe that is because I am associating
the name of the hotel with the communistic and rather free love com-
munity of Oneida, New York, of those times. The name Oneida as late
as 1900 was somewhat associated with free love sex colonies and so I
doubt if it was considered a high class hotel at that time. I might
be entirely wrong in this thinking.

Every one of the hotels which he has checked has long since gone the
way of all the earth with the exception of the Hotel English, and I
understand it is rather soon to be torn down. I would be strongly in-
clined to doubt if the register lists have been preserved that far back,
or would be available. You might try the English Hotel, however. Almost
certainly the register lists of all the others are lost.

I shall be very happy if this has been of any use to you. I assure you
that you will be quite welcome to the use of the cut showing the room
in which Walter Reed read his paper. We did have an original photo-
graph and we might find it again, or I suppose we might find one from
another source. I shall continue to be on the lookout for it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Thurman B. Rice, M. D.
Professor of Public Health TBR/s
